data.title: Uruguay Trade Deficit Widens in September
data.description:
Uruguay’s trade deficit widened to USD 16.94 million in September 2025 from USD 11.94 million a year earlier.

Imports rose 4.7% year-on-year to USD 1,184.1 million.

Purchases of consumer goods increased 4.3%, supported by a 1.4% rise in food and beverages and a 1.1% gain in vehicles.

Imports of capital goods grew 1.1%, with machinery and equipment up 1.4%, while purchases of intermediate goods declined 0.3% as oil and distillate imports fell 3.1%.

Exports rose 12.9% to USD 1,167.2 million, driven by primary products (+19.5%) and manufactured goods (+10.3%), while utilities exports fell 14.3%.

California City of Manteca to Sell $48 Million of Wastewater Revenue Bonds
data.description:
By Chris Wack

The Manteca Financing Authority of California plans to issue $48 million of bonds to finance improvements in its wastewater system.

Proceeds from the Series 2025 Wastewater Revenue Bonds will also be used to refinance the Series 2009 sewer revenue bonds and City of Manteca Series 2012 sewer revenue bonds, according to a document posted Thursday on MuniOS.

The bonds will provide about $30 million for improvements to Manteca's wastewater system, including work on a dewatering unit, a sludge thickener unit, and the wastewater system's collection system.

Pricing is scheduled for Nov. 6 and closing is set for Nov. 25.

The bonds are special obligations of the authority and repayment is secured by a pledge of revenue from the wastewater system of the city.

Interest is payable starting on June 1 and again Dec. 1. The securities are subject to optional redemption starting on Dec. 1, 2035. The bonds reach final maturity in December 2055.

The Manteca Financing Authority was created in 1991 for the purpose of issuing bonds to finance the purchase, construction and improvement of certain capital improvements for the city. Located in San Joaquin County, Manteca is about 75 miles east of San Francisco.

S&P Global Ratings assigned the bonds a rating of AA.

Ramirez & Co. is lead underwriter.

Write to Chris.Wack@wsj.com

data.title: LKQ Corp reports results for the quarter ended September 30 - Earnings Summary
data.description:
• LKQ Corp reported quarterly adjusted earnings of 84 cents​​ per share for the quarter ended September 30, lower than the same quarter last year, when the company reported EPS of 88 cents. The mean expectation of seven analysts for the quarter was for earnings of 76 cents per share. Wall Street expected results to range from 63 cents to 83 cents per share.

  • Revenue fell 2.4% to $3.50 billion from a year ago; analysts expected $3.54 billion.

  • LKQ Corp's reported EPS for the quarter was 70 cents​.

  • The company reported quarterly net income of $180 million.

  • LKQ Corp shares had risen by 2.0% this quarter and lost 15.2% so far this year.

FORECAST CHANGES

  • The mean earnings estimate of analysts had fallen by about 6.6% in the last three months.​

  • In the last 30 days, there have been no negative revisions of earnings estimates

RECOMMENDATIONS

  • The current average analyst rating on the shares is "buy" and the breakdown of recommendations is 7 "strong buy" or "buy," 2 "hold" and no "sell" or "strong sell." The average consensus recommendation for the auto, truck & motorcycle parts peer group is also "buy"

  • Wall Street's median 12-month price target for LKQ Corp is $44.26, about 29.6% above its last closing price of $31.16

Freedom Farms to Attend the 51st Annual New Orleans Investment Conference
data.description:
Jayuya, Puerto Rico--(Newsfile Corp. - October 31, 2025) - Freedom Farms announced today that it will be participating in the 51st Annual New Orleans Investment Conference at the Hilton New Orleans Riverside November 2 - 5, 2025. Mike Maloney, Founder, will be presenting and is looking forward to networking with investors during the Conference - see below for exact times. 

The New Orleans Investment Conference gathers some of the world’s brightest and most successful analysts, newsletter writers and investors. This year’s event will highlight all major asset classes, including Agriculture.

About Freedom Farms

Freedom Farms is a 900-acre organic, regenerative farm in Puerto Rico's mountains, focused on reversing environmental impact while producing premium food through permaculture practices. The operation combines atmospheric carbon sequestration with off-grid clean energy and market-leading agricultural production.

New Orleans Investment Conference Details: Mr. Maloney will be part of the Opening Event, Sunday November 2nd, from 4pm to 7:05pm in the Grand Ballroom, as well as two Main Stage presentations on Monday November 3rd, at 11:35am, and again at 7:25pm. And(!) There is also a yet-to-be-disclosed closing event where Mike is part of an all-star panel. Mike and the Freedom Farms team will be at BOOTH #327 and we look forward to speaking with you about this long-awaited visionary overhaul in agriculture.

About The New Orleans Investment Conference

The New Orleans Investment Conference is the one place where the world’s most sophisticated investors gather every year to discover new opportunities and strategies, exchange ideas, plan for the coming year and enjoy the camaraderie of like-minded individuals in America’s most fascinating and entertaining city.

Headliners at the New Orleans Conference over the last 50 years have included Lady Margaret Thatcher, former President Gerald Ford, novelist Ayn Rand, General H. Norman Schwarzkopf, Nobel Prize-winning economists Milton Friedman and F.A. Hayek, Dr. Henry Kissinger, Senator Barry Goldwater, Admiral Hyman Rickover, Louis Rukeyser, Sir John Templeton, Lord William Rees-Mogg, Charlton Heston, Jeane Kirkpatrick, Robert Bleiberg, Jack Kemp, William F. Buckley, General Colin Powell, Ron Paul and J. Peter Grace, among hundreds of other notables.

This year’s speakers line-up includes the likes of Matt Taibbi…Rick Rule...Mary Katharine Ham…Danielle DiMartino Booth…Brent Johnson…George Gammon…Peter St. Onge…Viva Frei…Robert Kiyosaki…Peter Boockvar…Jim Bianco…Jim Iuorio…Adam Taggart…Peter Schiff…Adrian Day…Mike Maloney…Alex Green…Dave Collum…Robert Prechter…Robert Helms…Russ Gray…

PLUS Mark Skousen...Lawrence Lepard…Jordan Roy-Byrne…Dan Oliver…Jeff Phillips…Lobo Tiggre…Tavi Costa…Nick Hodge…Chris Powell…Dana Samuelson…Jennifer Shaigec…Rich Checkan…Thom Calandra…Mary Anne & Pamela Aden…Omar Ayales…Bill Murphy…Gerardo Del Real…Steve Hochberg…Albert Lu…Lindsay Hall...Kerry Stevenson… and more, including Brien Lundin, host of this illustrious event.

Don’t miss out. Register for the 51st Annual New Orleans Investment Conference by clicking here.

For additional information, please contact:

Freedom Farms

Phil Sarsons

Senior Project Developer

2508259264

phil@freedomfarmspr.com 

https://www.ffpr.farm/

data.title: Trump says US, Canada will not restart trade talks
data.description:
U.S. President Donald Trump said on Friday the United States and Canada will not restart trade talks but Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney apologized to him for an Ontario political ad using former President Ronald Reagan saying tariffs spell disaster.

"I like him a lot but what they did was wrong," he said. "He apologized for what they did with the commercial because it was a false commercial."

Carney did not immediately respond to requests for comment.

Trump last week called off negotiations over the advertisement aired by the Canadian province of Ontario, adding he was increasing tariffs on Canada by an additional 10%.

The ad by the Ontario government featured Republican icon Reagan saying that tariffs on foreign goods while lead to trade wars and job losses.

Reagan was known for his support of free markets and free trade.

data.title: Yen faces worst monthly drop since July as BOJ disappoints
data.description:
Key points:
  • BOJ holds rates, disappoints traders hoping for hawkish stance
  • Fed dampens expectations for December rate cut, dollar gains
  • Euro and sterling fall as ECB and BOE maintain rates

By Karen Brettell

The Japanese yen was heading for a monthly loss against the U.S. dollar on Friday after the Bank of Japan disappointed traders hoping for a more hawkish stance on future rate hikes, while the Federal Reserve dampened expectations for a December rate cut.

The yen clawed back some losses after Japanese Finance Minister Satsuki Katayama said the government has been monitoring foreign exchange movements with a high sense of urgency as the yen weakens.

Core inflation in Tokyo also accelerated in October and stayed above the central bank's 2% target, data showed on Friday.

But disappointment after BOJ Governor Kazuo Ueda adopted a less hawkish tone on future rate hikes than hoped held the yen in check. The Japanese central bank kept rates on hold at 0.5%.

Noel Dixon, global macro strategist at State Street Global Markets, said he remains constructive on the yen, adding that “the BOJ ultimately is still going to have to normalize policy at least to 1%.”

“From a multi-year perspective, wages are definitely higher than they've been … and the fiscal spending is only going to exacerbate that prospect,” Dixon said.

Japan’s newly elected leader, Sanae Takaichi, is expected to pursue more fiscally expansive policies to boost economic growth.

The yen was last flat on the day and heading for its worst month since July, with the dollar up 4.2% against the currency this month.

The dollar index rose 0.35% to 99.82 and is on track for a 2% monthly gain, its best since July.

DIVIDED FEDERAL RESERVE

The greenback has been boosted by optimism over the economic outlook even as the labor market weakens, while Fed policymakers remain concerned about inflation.

Fed Chair Jerome Powell said on Wednesday that a policy divide within the U.S. central bank and a lack of federal government data may put another interest rate cut out of reach this year.

“It sounded like he was just trying to give himself some optionality,” said Dixon.

The Fed cut rates on Wednesday, as expected, though two policymakers dissented. Governor Stephen Miran again called for a deeper reduction in borrowing costs, while Kansas City Fed President Jeffrey Schmid favored no cut.

Schmid said on Friday that he dissented out of concern that continued high inflation and signs of price pressures spreading in the economy could raise doubts about the central bank's commitment to its 2% inflation target.

Dallas Fed President Lorie Logan said on Friday that the Fed should not have cut interest rates this week and Cleveland Fed President Beth Hammack said she also opposed the rate cut.

Atlanta Fed President Raphael Bostic said on Friday a December rate cut is not locked in.

Fed funds futures traders are pricing in a 63% probability of a cut in December, down from 93% a week ago, according to the CME Group’s FedWatch Tool.

Dixon said he expects the dollar index to consolidate under technical resistance at around 102, before gaining next year when growth is likely to accelerate.

“From a positioning standpoint, it's clear that investors, at least from a real money perspective, are maxed out from a short perspective, so I think it's difficult to short it,” he added.

EURO, STERLING DROP

The euro dropped 0.37% to $1.1522 after the European Central Bank kept interest rates unchanged at 2% for the third meeting in a row on Thursday and repeated that policy was in a "good place" as economic risks recede. The single currency has fallen 1.8% this month, as the dollar gains broadly.

Sterling fell 0.14% to $1.3132, the lowest since April 14, as political pressures grew surrounding British Finance Minister Rachel Reeves. Against the euro, the pound reached its weakest since May 2023.

The pound is heading for a 2.3% drop this month, while gilt yields have dropped on concern over what Reeves' November budget might mean for businesses, households and overall economic activity.

Traders are also pricing in rising odds of a Bank of England interest rate cut, though the British central bank is viewed as most likely keeping rates on hold when it meets next week.

"While we think GBP sentiment has turned overly bearish, we have long argued against fading the move ahead of the Budget, not to mention the tail risk of the BoE cutting rates next week," Bank of America analysts said in a report.

In cryptocurrencies, bitcoin gained 1.34% to $108,972.

data.title: STARRY SEA ACQUISITION CORP SEC 10-Q Report
data.description:
Starry Sea Acquisition Corp, a blank check company incorporated in the Cayman Islands, has released its Form 10-Q report for the quarter ended September 30, 2025. The report provides a comprehensive overview of the company's financial performance and operational activities, highlighting key metrics and recent developments.

Financial Highlights

  • Net Income: $70,389 for the three months ended September 30, 2025, reflecting interest earned on cash held in the Trust Account of $323,479, partially offset by formation and operating costs of $253,090.
  • Net Loss: $(36,715) for the nine months ended September 30, 2025, due to formation and operating costs of $360,194, partially offset by interest earned on cash held in the Trust Account of $323,479.
  • Basic and diluted net income per ordinary shares subject to possible redemption: $0.15 for the three months ended September 30, 2025.
  • Basic and diluted net income per ordinary shares subject to possible redemption: $0.65 for the nine months ended September 30, 2025.
  • Basic and diluted loss, ordinary shares attributable to Starry Sea Acquisition Corp: $(0.23) for the three months ended September 30, 2025.
  • Basic and diluted loss, ordinary shares attributable to Starry Sea Acquisition Corp: $(0.48) for the nine months ended September 30, 2025.

Business Highlights

  • Business Overview: Starry Sea Acquisition Corp is focused on effecting a merger, share exchange, asset acquisition, share purchase, recapitalization, reorganization, or similar business combination with one or more target businesses. The company is not limited to a particular industry or geographic location for its business combination efforts.
  • Operational Activities: As of September 30, 2025, the company had not commenced any operations. All activities to date have been related to the company's formation and the initial public offering (IPO). The company will not generate any operating revenues until after the completion of a business combination.
  • Recent Developments: On September 29, 2025, Starry Sea entered into a letter of intent with Forever Young International Limited, a health industry operator in China, for a proposed business combination. The pre-money equity value for Forever Young is expected to be between $750 million and $900 million, with consideration in the form of rollover equity valued at $10 per share.
  • Future Outlook: The company has a 15-month period from the effective date of its registration statement to complete its initial business combination. If unable to do so, the company will cease operations and redeem public shares. The management has broad discretion with respect to the application of net proceeds from the IPO and private placement, primarily aimed at consummating a business combination.
  • Segment Information: The Chief Executive Officer (CEO) acts as the Chief Operating Decision Maker (CODM), reviewing the company's performance as a whole. The company currently operates as a single segment, with no operating income or revenue until a business combination is completed.
  • Liquidity and Capital Resources: The company's liquidity needs have been met through the IPO proceeds and a private placement. A total of $57,500,000 was placed in a trust account, with funds intended for use in connection with the initial business combination and related expenses.
  • Administrative Support Services: The company has agreed to pay an affiliate of the Sponsor $10,000 per month for office space, utilities, and administrative support, which will continue until the completion of a business combination or liquidation.

SEC Filing: STARRY SEA ACQUISITION CORP [ SSEAU ] - 10-Q - Oct. 31, 2025

data.title: ACCO BRANDS Corp SEC 10-Q Report
data.description:
ACCO BRANDS Corp, a global leader in consumer, technology, and business branded products, has released its Form 10-Q report for the third quarter of 2025. The report provides a comprehensive overview of the company's financial performance and operational highlights, reflecting the challenges and strategic initiatives undertaken during the period.

Financial Highlights

  • Net Sales: $383.7 million, decreased by 8.8% compared to the prior year's third quarter, reflecting softer global demand for consumer and business products.
  • Gross Profit: $126.6 million, decreased by 7.5% due to volume declines and unfavorable fixed-cost absorption, partly offset by savings from global cost reduction actions.
  • Operating Income: $26.0 million, slightly decreased by 1.1% from the prior year, impacted by lower sales volume and unfavorable fixed-cost absorption, offset by cost reduction actions.
  • Net Income: $4.0 million, decreased by 57.0% compared to the prior year's third quarter, primarily due to lower sales volume and higher income tax expense.
  • Diluted Income Per Share: $0.04, decreased by 55.6% from the prior year's third quarter, reflecting the decline in net income.

Business Highlights

  • Revenue Segments: ACCO Brands operates through two main segments: ACCO Brands Americas and ACCO Brands International. The Americas segment includes the United States, Canada, and Latin America, while the International segment covers EMEA, Australia/New Zealand, and Asia. Each segment designs, markets, sources, manufactures, and sells consumer, technology, and business branded products.
  • Geographical Performance: In the Americas, net sales decreased by 12.2% for the three months ended September 30, 2025, primarily due to lower demand for consumer and business products. In the International segment, net sales decreased by 3.5%, with favorable foreign exchange partially offsetting the decline. The decrease was driven by reduced demand for business products.
  • Sales Units: The company experienced a decline in sales volume, with the Americas segment reporting a 12.9% decrease in volume for the three months ended September 30, 2025. The International segment saw a 9.0% decrease in volume, primarily due to reduced demand for business products.
  • New Product Launches: The acquisition of Buro Seating Limited Partnership expanded ACCO Brands' presence in the ergonomic seating category in Australia and New Zealand, adding new product offerings to their portfolio.
  • Future Outlook: The company anticipates continued uncertainty in demand due to global economic conditions and evolving trade policies. ACCO Brands is taking actions such as price increases, sourcing adjustments, and SKU rationalization to mitigate the impact of tariffs and improve operational efficiency.
  • Operational Challenges: The company faced challenges from softer global demand, lower consumer and office spending, and geopolitical instability, which impacted their operational performance during the reporting period.
  • Cost Reduction Initiatives: ACCO Brands implemented global cost reduction actions, which helped offset some of the negative impacts from tariffs and lower sales volume. These initiatives are part of a broader restructuring and cost savings program aimed at achieving $100 million in annualized pre-tax cost savings by the end of 2026.

SEC Filing: ACCO BRANDS Corp [ ACCO ] - 10-Q - Oct. 31, 2025

data.title: Wheat Futures Rise as Traders Close Out Month — Daily Grain Highlights
data.description:
By Kirk Maltais

  • Wheat for December delivery rose 1.8% to $5.33 1/4 a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade Friday, as traders got their books in order on the last business day of the month.
  • Soybeans for January delivery rose 0.7% to $11.15 1/2 a bushel.
  • Corn for December delivery rose 0.3% to $4.31 1/2 a bushel.

HIGHLIGHTS

Leading the Push: CBOT grains rallied in afternoon trading despite the U.S. dollar showing strength throughout the day, with the WSJ Dollar Index up 0.2%. Typically, a stronger U.S. dollar makes U.S. grain exports less attractive for global customers versus the exports of other countries. Seemingly outweighing this uptick in the dollar is the desire of traders to get their books in order ahead of the weekend, said Brady Huck of Advance Trading.

The Next Episode: The agricultural market is now looking past the U.S.-China deal and spent the day searching for the next major mover of futures. "Grain action and volume slowed considerably overnight with the U.S.-China trade deal having come and gone," said Matt Zeller of StoneX in a note. Zeller adds that with the government shut down, it will be difficult for traders and analysts to get confirmation of whether or not China is following through with promised purchases, although reports of cargoes did circulate today.

INSIGHT

Going the Distance: Some analysts are unsure if soybean purchasing under the pending U.S.-China trade truce will take place as promised, even amid reports of Chinese buyers securing some new soybean cargoes. One reason is because there are no penalties described to enforce China's purchasing of 12 million metric tons of soybeans in this marketing year, along with 25 million tons of soybeans annually for the following three years. "Whether China secures 25 MMTs in future years depends on the price relationships between South America and the U.S." AgResource said in a note. "China buys what China needs at the cheapest price offered — it's that simple."

Dried Out: The U.S. Drought Monitor, which has remained in operation through the government shutdown, is showing dryness spread throughout the eastern Corn Belt states. Ohio, Indiana, Illinois, and Missouri all have small pockets of extreme or exceptional drought, according to the latest map, but also large areas of dry conditions ranging from abnormally dry to severe drought. The USDA's Crop Progress report has not been published since late September, so traders and analysts are unsure of crop conditions through the harvest — but the dryness likely hasn't helped those conditions.

AHEAD

Note: The government shutdown is impacting the timing of USDA reports and data releases.

-Zoetis Inc. will release its third quarter earnings report at 7 a.m. ET Tuesday.

-Mosaic Co. will release its third quarter earnings report after the stock market closes on Tuesday.

-Tyson Foods Co. will release its fourth quarter earnings report at 7:30 a.m. ET Monday.

Write to Kirk Maltais at kirk.maltais@wsj.com

data.title: Growing U.S.-Venezuela tensions, new OPEC+ targets mark a crucial week for oil ahead
data.description:
By Myra P. Saefong

The crude-oil market is seeing a 'rare occasion' where supply risks are more focused on the Americas

Any potential U.S. strike on Venezuela's military sites could pave the way for Venezuela's elected government to return to power - and that raises significant risks for oil markets, said the Price Futures Group's Phil Flynn.

Escalating U.S. tensions with Venezuela and an upcoming monthly decision by major oil producers on crude output targets were the focus of traders heading into the weekend.

The U.S. plans to attack military installations inside Venezuela and the strikes could come at any moment, the Miami Herald reported Friday, citing sources with knowledge of the situation.

In response to the report, White House Deputy Press Secretary Anna Kelly told MarketWatch in an email that "unnamed sources don't know what they're talking about. Any announcements regarding Venezuela policy would come directly from the President."

Still, oil prices found some support in the wake of the news report of potential strikes, with U.S. benchmark West Texas Intermediate crude for December delivery (CLZ25) (CL.1) edging up by 0.6% to $60.93 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Prices were still trading lower for the week and have declined for the month.

Although the U.S. already has certain sanctions on Venezuela in place, "those do not impact physical [oil] production and transport in the same way that possible damage from military activity could," Colin Cieszynski, portfolio manager and chief market strategist at SIA Wealth Management, told MarketWatch. "So this appears to be forcing investors to adjust their supply-risk expectations."

This is a "rare occasion," Cieszynski noted, where "supply risks are more focused in the Americas." He pointed out that U.S. crude prices were up a bit more than global benchmark Brent crude, which saw its January contract (BRNF26) - which becomes the front month at the end of the session - move up by 0.4% to $64.62 on ICE Futures Europe.

A U.S. strike on Venezuela's military sites would potentially pave the way for Venezuela's elected government to return to power, said Phil Flynn, senior market analyst at the Price Futures Group. "This raises significant risks for oil markets, particularly diesel, as supplies are already low and Venezuelan heavy oil is an important source."

The situation, meanwhile, could overshadow concerns about the recent sanctions on Russia's two largest oil companies, Rosneft Oil Company and Lukoil OAO, said Flynn.

Oil traders also are anticipating the latest decision by the major oil producers known as OPEC+ over the weekend. The group plans to hold its monthly meeting on Sunday and is expected to decide on production targets for the month of December.

At the last meeting in early October, OPEC+ agreed to increase production in November by another 137,000 barrels a day, despite rising concerns of a global supply glut. The group has been announcing monthly production increases since April.

In 2026, the global oil market may see an average surplus of 4 million barrels per day, according to reports from the International Energy Agency and World Bank Group.

Read: An oil supply glut could sink prices to $35 a barrel next year. Why the U.S.-China trade truce won't change that.

For the short term, analysts were expecting oil officials to announce a similar rise of 137,000 barrels per day in production targets, said David Morrison, senior market analyst at Trade Nation.

But long term, it looks as if the oil market wants to go lower, retesting the double bottom from this past May of $55 front-month WTI, he said in emailed comments to MarketWatch Friday.

"The reason is simply the ongoing slowdown in global demand growth, against recent reports that there will be a supply overhang of around 4 million bpd next year," said Morrison. "That could be countered by U.S. sanctions on Rosneft/Lukoil, but I don't think traders put much store in the effectiveness of sanctions. Maybe this time it's different."

-Myra P. Saefong

This content was created by MarketWatch, which is operated by Dow Jones & Co. MarketWatch is published independently from Dow Jones Newswires and The Wall Street Journal.

data.title: Nasdaq rises on Amazon boost but Fed worries, benefits expiry add caution
data.description:
Key points:
  • Indexes up: Dow 0.08%, S&P 500 up 0.32%, Nasdaq up 0.73%
  • Amazon jumps as cloud growth beats expectations
  • Apple forecasts upbeat holiday-quarter iPhone sales
  • Warner Bros jumps after Reuters report of Netflix bid

By Sinéad Carew and Pranav Kashyap

The Nasdaq index advanced faster than the S&P 500 and the Dow on Friday with a strong boost from Amazon's upbeat earnings forecast, but worries about hawkish Federal Reserve commentary and the potential expiry of government food aid benefits dampened the investor mood.

Amazon shares jumped 11%, hitting an all-time high after the online retailer forecast quarterly sales above estimates. Apple's forecast for iPhone sales in the holiday quarter surpassed Wall Street expectations late on Thursday, but CEO Tim Cook flagged supply constraints. Its shares were last flat.

Nvidia , which became the first publicly listed firm to surpass $5 trillion in market value earlier this week, was up 0.7% after CEO Jensen Huang said he hoped the company's state-of-the-art Blackwell chips could be sold in China.

But in remarks that cooled investor hopes, Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta President Raphael Bostic said on Friday that a December rate cut is not locked in despite market expectations for a cut. Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland President Beth Hammack said she had opposed Wednesday's rate cut because inflation is too high.

On Friday, traders were pricing in a 63% probability of a December rate cut, down from 72.8% on Thursday, according to CME Group's FedWatch tool.

"Investors may have gotten in front of their skis a little bit and thinking, 'OK, going to get lower rates,' and maybe that will lead to some broadening of market performance, maybe get some economic tailwinds to certain cyclical sectors," said Jake Seltz, portfolio manager for the Empiric LT Equity team at Allspring.

Some grocery stocks traded lower on Friday on worries about a dip in November sales if federal food aid benefits, known as the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program or SNAP, lapse due to the ongoing government shutdown. However, a federal judge in Rhode Island on Friday blocked President Donald Trump's administration from suspending all food aid for millions of Americans.

Shares of grocer Kroger were down 2.9% while shares of Conagra Brands were off 1.8% and Walmart shares dropped 1.2%.

"Earlier, everybody got a boost from Amazon," said Kim Forrest, chief investment officer of Bokeh Capital, adding that the Amazon boost gradually faded as Friday's market was "like a slowly leaking balloon rather than pin pop."

Forrest said investors, including mutual funds at the end of their fiscal year, may have taken a pause after a strong month. She also noted some signs of fears in grocery stocks in the face of a potential SNAP program expiry.

At 2:25 p.m. EDT, the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 38.02 points, or 0.08%, to 47,560.14, the S&P 500 gained 22.13 points, or 0.32%, to 6,844.47 and the Nasdaq Composite gained 171.09 points, or 0.73%, to 23,752.23.

AI frenzy pushed Wall Street to record highs earlier this week before concerns about major spending from Microsoft and Meta as well as doubts about further interest rate cuts from the Federal Reserve spooked investors.

For the month, the S&P 500 was higher, putting it on track for a sixth consecutive monthly gain - its longest such streak since August 2021.

The Nasdaq Composite was on pace for a seventh consecutive monthly advance, while the Dow was set for its sixth straight monthly win - their longest runs since January 2018.

Of the 315 S&P 500 companies that have reported third-quarter results so far, 83.2% have surpassed analysts' estimates, according to LSEG data. That is well above the historical average, where roughly 67% of firms beat forecasts.

In other moves, Warner Bros Discovery rose 3.8% following a Reuters report that Netflix was actively exploring a bid for the company's studio and streaming business.

Netflix added 2.8% as it unveiled plans for a 10-for-1 stock split.

Getty Images rose 2.7% after signing a global multiyear licensing agreement with Perplexity AI.

Western Digital gained 6.7% to an all-time high after forecasting quarterly earnings above Wall Street estimates.

Solar panel maker First Solar surged 13.4% to a more than one-year high after surpassing expectations for third quarter sales.

Advancing issues outnumbered decliners by a 1.04-to-1 ratio on the NYSE where there were 124 new highs and 122 new lows.

On the Nasdaq, 2,467 stocks rose and 2,138 fell as advancing issues outnumbered decliners by a 1.15-to-1 ratio. The S&P 500 posted 16 new 52-week highs and 34 new lows while the Nasdaq Composite recorded 65 new highs and 151 new lows.

data.title: Here Are the Best and Worst States for Taxes. Guess Which Ranks Last? — Barrons.com
data.description:
By Kenneth Corbin

State tax codes, like their federal counterpart, can be incredibly complex and are subject to frequent revisions. But the absence of a major tax — such as a sales tax, or levies on corporate or individual income — is a theme of many of the states that top a new ranking of tax policies around the country.

The Tax Foundation, a nonpartisan think tank that often favors policies to reduce or simplify tax burdens, looked at more than 150 variables to compile its annual ranking of the most and least favorable states, published on Thursday.

The winner? Wyoming, a sparsely populated western state with no corporate or individual income tax, tops the Tax Foundation's list. South Dakota, a state with a similar profile that also doesn't tax corporate or individual income, is No. 2.

The others in the Tax Foundation's top five also don't impose one or more of the major taxes. New Hampshire and Alaska, which both don't have a statewide sales tax or individual income tax, ranked Nos. 3 and 4, respectively. Florida, which has no individual income tax, ranked No. 5 on the list.

At the other end of the spectrum, the Tax Foundation ranked New York the state with the worst tax environment. The researchers cited its high individual income rate, the benefit recapture policy that phases out benefits from lower rates, and the imposition of local taxes in areas like New York City, among other factors.

The ranking's methodology weighs factors such as rates and complexity and groups the variables it considers into the five categories of corporate taxes, individual income taxes, sales and excise taxes, property and wealth taxes, and unemployment insurance taxes.

The Tax Foundation dinged the second-lowest ranked state, New Jersey, for levying taxes in all the major categories, "typically at high rates and significant levels of complexity."

The group awarded California the third-lowest spot on the list, followed by Connecticut and Maryland.

It cites California's high rates and a tax structure the researchers say is hostile to businesses, including the assessment of corporate tax on certain out-of-state income that would be tax-free in other states. "The state has a great deal going for it," the researchers say, citing California's research universities, moderate climate, and Silicon Valley, "but a tax code that is uncompetitive and threatens to get worse is increasingly driving jobs to other states."

Connecticut gets a poor score both because of its high rates and an individual tax code that is "one of the most complex" and progressive in the country, the analysts say.

Maryland has one of the most progressive individual tax codes in the country, and state lawmakers recently created two new tax brackets for the highest earners, according to the Tax Foundation's analysis.

Among the states the Tax Foundation deems most favorable, Wyoming and South Dakota, Nos. 1 and 2, are the only two states that don't tax corporate or individual income and don't impose a gross receipts tax, which applies to a company's gross sales.

The analysts lauded New Hampshire for taking steps to make its corporate tax structure more competitive and noted that it phased out taxes on interest and dividends at the beginning of this year, "further solidifying the state's competitive standing."

Alaska ranks highly due to its lack of individual income tax and sales tax, but the Tax Foundation notes that it could improve its policy framework by lowering corporate and property taxes and blocking cities and boroughs from setting their own sales-tax rates.

The Tax Foundation credits Florida for not imposing an individual income-tax rate and having a reasonable corporate rate, as well as a sales tax rate that is lower than many other southern states.

This content was created by Barron's, which is operated by Dow Jones & Co. Barron's is published independently from Dow Jones Newswires and The Wall Street Journal.
